content.description:
First done in 2004 by Philip Mothena and Edward Lyman. We now know that these crushers called it Shrinking Arête. 

   Sit start and the low right edge of the arête on the small block at the base. Use the low side-pull and far right foot at the low right side of the base. Lurch up and right to a pocket or higher sloper. Follow the low side of the arête to the top where you will negotiate the crimp rail. Swing feet left once on the crimp rail to a distant left foot hold and commence the tricky top out. 

  -As a side note, there is a resident bat that sleeps under the huge undercling hold to the far back of the boulder. Please do not disturb this little dude. Hes just chillin' and there is no problem near him... Even if there were, its his house so dont mess with him.

Whether you're looking for a tough arête boulder problem or a perfect place to chill by a picturesque stream, I would recommend this spot to check out. 

  With a relaxing creek 5ft away, a flat landing, and a steep arête line to work, Shadow Cast is a perfect setting for a session. 

  "Shadow Cast" has tricky beta, slopey core intensive holds, crimps, and long lock-offs.  

  -As a side note, there is a resident little bat that sleeps under the huge undercling hold to the far back of the boulder to the left. Please do not disturb this little dude. Hes just chillin' and there is not problem near him... Even if there were, its his house so dont mess with him. He's the Shadow Cast bat. Respect.
